Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 0554c984827c1593663257a842d0cd943ce4f508 by Ed Tanous
Topic wip removed

You should read in all your parameters in one readJson call.

something like

readJson(req, res, "TransferProtocol", transferProtocol, "ImageURI", imageURI);

Otherwise you will get conflicting error messages about missing parameters.
Thanks! This fixed it.
You might consider throwing this check inside the conditional on line 240.
Done
Yeah, the spec as far as I've seen is pretty light and I can't find any examples. I'll see if I can get anything out of the DMTF meeting or maybe a github issue to the DMTF github repo.

Forgot to call res.end() here.

The current state-of-the-art is to use the AsyncResp object in all cases, so you get RAII to call res.end() automatically, instead of it being manual.
Done
Rename to timeoutTimeSeconds just to make it clear?
Done

Looking at this, using this constructor actually doesn't do anything.... I wonder why it's here.

Not your problem, but I suspect that statement can be deleted.
Yeah, it is a bit weird to pass in the timeout to the constructor and then pass it in again in the next statement. I'll remove and see what happens.

Yeah, this did cause the returned error when a param was missing to have both PropertyMissing and ActionParameterMissing in the return error. I'll just remove the extra log. Seems to be the additional logic you have above of checking transferProtocol and imageURI is a bit redundant with the checks I already have? The readJson will at least ensure the parameter is present and something has been passed for them then my code below ensures the format is correct for them.

Did you get any answers from the Redfish guys on this?


I wonder if the usecase validator has any tests for this.
I put up a forum post at https://redfishforum.com/thread/193/imageuri-updateservice. Lets see if we get anything back there.

They responded that with our implementation here, where we require both ImageURI and TRansferProtocol that the correct format is what we've got here:
"ImageURI": "<server ip>/<firmware image>",
This should be the imageURI variable to get the  right behavior.

hmm, I don't think so? The trace in that error msg is:

"The value " + arg1 + " for the parameter " + arg2 +
" in the action " + arg3 +
" is of a different type than the parameter can accept."}

Seems like arg3 should be the name of the action we're in?
I don't think we can let the HTTP connection go idle for up to 2 minutes.  I believe this is where Redfish would recommend returning a task service entry to allow checking status.
Yeah, this is def where the task feature comes into play. For now should we just return to the caller once the TFTP download has started (vs. completed)?

From a users standpoint, I kind of like the connection hanging until the download has completed. But could def be a user preference. What do you want me to do? I'm up for anything but enabling tasks :)
That might be a short term option.  We need to figure something else long term.
Good.
Should we prefix this with BMCWEB_INSECURE given that it is known to be insecure?
Done
Did you double check this with PrivilegeRegistry?  I thought it was ConfigureManager.

Aren't all these chosen by the implementation? Or is there somewhere that defines these for each object? I'll trust you and change to ConfigureManager.  https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/PrivilegeRegistry.v1_1_3.json and http://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/UpdateService.v1_5_0.json don't seem to define anything here?

Redfish standard registries is where the defaults for these are supposed to be coming from.

https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP8011_2019.1.zip

I really need to get those files checked into the codebase in a more obvious, and harder to screw up way.

Hostname, not necessarily IP.

Also, shouldn't we include decoding protocol in the URI?  I thought that was allowed in Redfish, and something that a user is very likely to do.

tftp://1.1.1.1/myfile.bin
Rather than explicitly setting the transfer protocol parameter.
Yep, added support for both the TransferProtocol parameter and encoding it in ImageURI
This isn't really going to fly in an http context.  Most libraries default to a 15-30 second timeout before assuming this didn't go to plan.
ok, I made it so we'll now return once TFTP starts.  https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/issues/75 and eventually the Task services can be used to track success/fail by the client.
A little weird... but I guess I'm ok with it.
Yeah, I'm never a fan of optional if/else type things like this but it enabled the most code reuse and handled the timing issues for TFTP.
Ahh cool, I did not know the json_util would handle that.
Technically this should be case-sensitive.  Right?

If they pass the TransferProtocol parameter, it's upper case, "TFTP". If they encode it in the ImageURI, then it's lower case. Since this was common code for both paths I just accept either. Better that I ensure the case is appropriate for both paths?

I'd prefer we're redfish compliant here.  Can we just call std::toupper on the string on line 272?  That way, if it comes through that path, it's case insensitive, which I think is the right behavior for URLs.  Then if it comes in through the TransferProtocol path, we're case sensitive as Redfish requires.  Sound reasonable?
TFTP?
Done
See comment on other commit.  Upper case your string here, then remove the iequals on line 263, and I think we get better behavior.
Done
I'm still not in love that we're writing our own network URI parser here and not pulling in a fully compliant one, but I guess I can live with it.
Yeah, when we add more then TFTP, I'll look into something more generic.
